Award.AwardTitle: CAP: Doctoral Consortium for the 2015 Learning Analytics and Knowledge Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Using data analytics has revolutionized many academic disciplines, such as Astrophysics and Biology. In addition, it has changed the commercial world and critical services like healthcare. The field of education research is also beginning this change. The Society for Learning Analytics Research (SoLAR) is a key player in effecting this change. This project will support a Doctoral Consortium at the SoLAR 2015 conference - the 5th Annual International Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) Conference, to be held in Poughkeepsie, NY in March 2015. Participating in the consortium will prepare current doctoral students from the diverse research backgrounds that make up the interdisciplinary field of Learning Analytics (LA), including computer science, information science, psychology, communication, education, artificial intelligence, and cognitive science. It will also allow them to network with each other and with professors and practitioners who are currently engaged in learning analytics research and related work to ensure the continued development of this community. These activities are critical and timely. The upcoming generation of LA researchers will play a vital role in realizing the potential of using data to improve outcomes for elementary, secondary, and post-secondary students in learning, motivation, and perseverance.

Learning Analytics is an interdisciplinary field whose goal is to advance and apply knowledge about learning sciences and education to improve all aspects of learning. LA methods include data visualization, data mining, data science, and mixed methods approaches combining qualitative and quantitative methods (e.g., interviews and back-end, clickstream data analysis). Capacity building is a central concern within the LA community. SoLAR has historically addressed these needs, in part, through specialized workshops held in conjunction with the Society's major conference. The Doctoral Consortium workshops host PhD students who are grappling with their dissertation research. This grant provides travel support to US scholars selected through a competitive application process to participate in this event. They present their work for feedback both in the context of workshop, where they receive advice from a panel of expert mentors, and in a poster session in which they interact with the full conference audience. In addition, their work is published in the proceedings of the conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interdisciplinarity is a hallmark of research in the new field of Learning Analytics. This is exciting, but also poses challenges to doctoral students to see how their thesis work- driven by the culture of their disciplinary training- may impact and intersect with larger issues in Learning Analytics. The major goal of the Doctoral Consortium held at the 2015 Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) conference was to provide an opportunity for advanced doctoral students to build community for the next generation of Learning Analytics scholars. The grand funding provided support for an international group of 4 faculty mentors and 4 PhD students from the United States

A total for nine doctoral students were selected from a pool of 24 applicants based on as assessment that their research was conceptually motivated, had implications for learning theory, and used analytics to provide direction for understanding and supporting learning processes and outcomes. The five students who were not from US institutions were supported by the Society for Research on Learning Analytics and Knowledge (SoLAR), the academic society that runs LAK annually. The student participants came from a diverse set of disciplinary programs, including science education, computer science, education, and human-computer interaction.

Overall, the workshop was considered to have successfully provided students with a broad interdisciplinary lens for considering their own and others' research. In a survey administered after the workshop, all of the student participants agreed with the statement, "I have learned about perspectives on learning analytics from participants not in my home discipline." Seventy-five percent of students reported that they learned about new research methodologies and identified potential new collaborators. Student indicated that the most useful aspects of the workshop were 1) the opportunity to present their research to the group, 2) the informal socializing with peers and mentors, and 3) the discussions with other LAK attendees. 

The combined funding from the NSF and SoLAR allowed the workshop to fully fund both US and international students, and to do so equally for all. In addition, the NSF funding allow the two Primary Investigators recruit international colleagues as mentors, which represented the fact that the Learning Analytics community is not only interdisciplinary but truly global.
